==Dissolution and ruin== [[Image:Turner Tintern1.jpg|thumb|upright|''The Chancel and Crossing of Tintern Abbey, Looking towards the East Window'' by [[J. M. W. Turner]], 1794]] In the reign of [[Henry VIII of England|King Henry VIII]], his [[Dissolution of the Monasteries]] ended monastic life in England, Wales and Ireland. On 3 September 1536, Abbot Wych surrendered Tintern Abbey and all its estates to the King's visitors and ended a way of life that had lasted 400 years. Valuables from the Abbey were sent to the [[Lord High Treasurer|royal Treasury]] and Abbot Wych was pensioned off. The building was granted to the then lord of Chepstow, [[Henry Somerset, 2nd Earl of Worcester]]. Lead from the roof was sold and the decay of the buildings began.
In the next two centuries little or no interest was shown in the history of the site. In the 17th and 18th centuries, the ruins were inhabited by workers in the local wire works.<ref name=newman/> However, in the mid-18th century it became fashionable to visit "wilder" parts of the country. The [[Wye Valley]] in particular was well known for its romantic and [[picturesque]] qualities and the ivy clad Abbey became frequented by tourists. One of the earliest prints of the Abbey was in the series of engravings of historical sites made in 1732 by [[Samuel and Nathaniel Buck]].<ref>Tintern Conservation Area survey, [http://www.monmouthshire.gov.uk/app/uploads/2015/08/Tintern-CAA-Main-Body-feb15.pdf p.13]</ref> After the publication of the book ''Observations on the River Wye'' by the Reverend [[William Gilpin (priest)|William Gilpin]] following his 1770 tour,<ref>[https://archive.org/details/observationsonr00gilpgoog Gilpin, William, 1724-1804: "Observations on the river Wye, and several parts of South Wales, etc. : relative chiefly to picturesque beauty: made in the summer of the year 1770." Archived online] Accessed 28 September 2017</ref> visitors greatly increased, a fact evidenced both by the number of poetic descriptions and of atmospheric paintings and prints of the site.
==Poetry and painting== A dedicatory letter at the start of Gilpin’s work is addressed to the poet [[William Mason (poet)|William Mason]] and mentions a similar tour made in 1771 by the poet [[Thomas Gray]]. Neither of those dedicated a poem to the Abbey, but it appeared in the work of a number of others, including Rev. Dr. Syned Davies’ long “Describing a Voyage to Tintern Abbey, in Monmouthshire, from Whitminster in Gloucestershire”, which was made by boat with a party of others as early as 1745.<ref>[http://www.lib.umich.edu/enchanting-ruin-tintern-abbey-romantic-tourism-wales/poetical.html#entry1 Rev. Dr. Syned Davies “A Voyage to Tintern Abbey, in Monmouthshire, from Whitminster in Gloucestershire”. Epistle IV, in “THE LANGUAGE OF THE SENSE” Poetical Tintern at lib.umich.edu] Accessed 28 September 2017</ref> Another topographical work, the six-canto ''Chepstow; or, A new guide to gentlemen and ladies whose curiosity leads them to visit Chepstow: Piercefield-walks, Tintern-abbey, and the beautiful romantic banks of the Wye, from Tintern to Chepstow by water'', was published from Bristol in 1786.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books/about/Chepstow_Or_A_New_Guide_to_Gentlemen_and.html?id=x509HQAACAAJ&redir_esc=y William Pine, 1786: "Chepstow; Or, A New Guide to Gentlemen and Ladies Whose Curiosity Leads Them to Visit Chepstow: Piercefield-walks, Tintern-abbey, etc." Google Books] Accessed 28 September 2017</ref> There was also the “Poetical description of Tintern Abbey” by the parson poet Rev. Duncomb Davis, who lived locally and furnished it with many historical and topical discursions, including the method of iron-making that took place adjacent to the site.<ref>[http://www.lib.umich.edu/enchanting-ruin-tintern-abbey-romantic-tourism-wales/poetical.html#entry6 Rev. Duncomb Davis' poem, in “THE LANGUAGE OF THE SENSE” Poetical Tintern at lib.umich.edu University of Michigan] Accessed 28 September 2017</ref> This appeared in two guide books, the most popular of which was [[Charles Heath (Monmouth)|Charles Heath]]'s ''Historical and Descriptive Accounts of the Ancient and Present State of Tintern Abbey'', that went through many editions from 1793 onwards.<ref>[http://www.lib.umich.edu/enchanting-ruin-tintern-abbey-romantic-tourism-wales/poetical.html#entry2poem, Charles Heath: "Historical and Descriptive Accounts of the Ancient and Present State of Tintern Abbey" in “THE LANGUAGE OF THE SENSE” Poetical Tintern at lib.umich.edu University of Michigan] Accessed 28 September 2017</ref>
William Wordsworth’s poem "[[Lines written a few miles above Tintern Abbey]], on revisiting the banks of the Wye during a tour, July 13, 1798", is often linked with the Abbey, although it does not actually mention the ruins.<ref>Deborah Kennedy, "Wordsworth, Turner, and the Power of Tintern Abbey", ''Wordsworth Circle'', [https://www.questia.com/library/journal/1G1-92803037/wordsworth-turner-and-the-power-of-tintern-abbey Spring 2002]</ref> Instead, it recalls an earlier visit five years before and comments on the beneficial internalisation of that memory.<ref>[http://www.rc.umd.edu/sites/default/RCOldSite/www/rchs/reader/tabbey.html Gilpin, William, Observations on the river Wye, and several parts of South Wales, Page 46: Online text at rc.umd.edu] Accessed 1 October 2017</ref> Following a similar walking tour with friends, [[Robert Bloomfield]] also dedicated a long poem to “The Banks of the Wye” (1811) in which the Abbey is only mentioned briefly as one of many items on the way.<ref>[https://www.rc.umd.edu/editions/wye/HTML/BanksOfWyeII.html Robert Bloomfield: The Banks of Wye: Poem Text II.65–88] Accessed 1 October 2017</ref> However, that was followed in 1825 by yet another long poem dealing with the area, annotated and in four books, by Edward Collins: ''Tintern Abbey or the Beauties of Piercefield'' (1825).<ref>[http://search.library.utoronto.ca/details?181452 Edward Collins "Tintern Abbey: or, The beauties of Piercefield: a poem: in four books: interspersed with illustrative notes" at University of Toronto] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref>
[[Edward Jerningham]]’s earlier short lyric, “Tintern Abbey”, written in 1796, followed Gilpin, whom he quoted, in commenting on the mournful lesson of the past.<ref>[https://books.google.fr/books?id=VrIDAAAAQAAJ&printsec=frontcover&hl=fr#v=onepage&q=Tintern&f=false Edward Jerningham “Tintern Abbey” in ''Poems and Plays'', Vol.2, p.135 at Google Books] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref> Two poems of about that time also moralised on a visit to the ruins. Edmund Gardner, in his “Sonnet written in Tintern Abbey”, concludes with the line that 'Man’s but a temple of a shorter date',<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=91E3AAAAMAAJ&lpg=PA119&ots=KWaDlqMO9o&dq=%E2%80%9CMan%E2%80%99s%20but%20a%20temple%20of%20a%20shorter%20date%E2%80%9D&pg=PA119#v=onepage&q=%E2%80%9CMan%E2%80%99s%20but%20a%20temple%20of%20a%20shorter%20date%E2%80%9D&f=false Edmund Gardner, “Sonnet written in Tintern Abbey”: The sonnet originally appeared pseudonymously, accompanying a similarly moralising sonnet on the Severn in ''The European Magazine'' vol.30, p.119 at Google Books] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref> while Luke Booker, in his “Original sonnet composed on leaving Tintern Abbey and proceeding with a party of friends down the River Wye to Chepstow”, hopes at death to sail as peacefully to the 'eternal Ocean'.<ref>Booker's sonnet appeared in [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ydplX3_4zP8C&lpg=PP126&ots=E7FymDVfjc&dq=Tintern!%20whose%20venerable%20arches&pg=PP126#v=onepage&q=Tintern!%20whose%20venerable%20arches&f=false Charles Heath’s guide to Tintern Abbey]</ref> [[Richard Monckton Milnes, 1st Baron Houghton|Richard Monckton Milnes]]' sonnet on “Tintern Abbey” dates from 1840.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/poetryforpeopleo00houg/poetryforpeopleo00houg_djvu.txt Richard Monckton Milnes: "Poetry for the People", p.87 “Tintern Abbey”] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref> It is also known that Tennyson’s “[[Tears, Idle Tears]]” (1847) was composed on a visit, but no mention of the Abbey appears there and the poem refers to personal feelings.<ref>James Gribble, ''Literary Education: a revaluation'', Cambridge University 1983, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=nGKMe9_3HjAC&lpg=PA59&ots=qCF5GWGtHy&dq=tears%20idle%20tears%20%20Tennyson's%20private%20situation&pg=PA58#v=onepage&q=tears%20idle%20tears%20%20Tennyson's%20private%20situation&f=false pp.58–61]</ref>
[[File:Tintern Abbey Gilpin.jpg|thumb|upright=1.15|left|An aquatint of the Abbey from Gilpin's ''Observations on the River Wye'']] In 1816, the abbey was made the backdrop to Sophia F. Ziegenhirt’s three-volume novel of Gothic horror, ''The Orphan of Tintern Abbey'',<ref>Marshall B. Tymn, ''Horror literature: a core collection and reference guide'', R.R.Bowker, 1981, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YHQWAQAAIAAJ&q=%22The+Orphan+of+Tintern+Abbey%22+Ziegenhirt&dq=%22The+Orphan+of+Tintern+Abbey%22+Ziegenhirt&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAzgKahUKEwj9oOO0xI3JAhVLaxQKHeTpDqI p.175]</ref> dismissed by ''[[The Monthly Review]]'' as “of the most ordinary class, in which the construction of the sentences and that of the story are equally confused.”<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=AAQwAAAAYAAJ&lpg=PA439&ots=_hX2wjTmLD&dq=Sophia%20F.%20Ziegenhirt%20%20%22Tintern%20Abbey%22&pg=PA439#v=onepage&q=Sophia%20F.%20Ziegenhirt%20%20%22Tintern%20Abbey%22&f=false Sophia F. Ziegenhirt "The Orphan of Tintern Abbey" The Monthly Review, Or, Literary Journal Vol.79, p.439 at Google Books] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref> In a much more successful novel published two years earlier, [[Jane Austen]] described the decorations of Fanny Price's sitting room at [[Mansfield Park]] that included three fashionable transparencies, one of which featured the Abbey.<ref>[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xcQNAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA135&lpg=PA135&dq=Mansfield+Park+++%22Tintern%22&source=bl&ots=ilzHncs3IE&sig=hqWnRgXeIwKBXmNCSEnnaxh9TT8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAmoVChMI0uLdubvDyAIViZgaCh0tHAbo#v=onepage&q=Mansfield%20Park%20%20%20%22Tintern%22&f=false Jane Austen: "Mansfield Park" Standard novels edition, London 1833, p.135, at Google Books] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref>
Gilpin’s work on the Wye dealt not simply with the picturesque as a pictorial quality but with the added appeal of Gothic associations, as in the case of Tintern Abbey.<ref>William Gilpin, ''Observations on the Rivery Wye'', London 1882, [https://archive.org/stream/observationsonr00gilpgoog#page/n82/mode/2up/search/Tintern+ pp.47]</ref> The visiting artists [[Francis Towne]] (1777),<ref>[http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/ZoomImage.aspx?image=http://www.christies.com/lotfinderimages/d56989/d5698942&IntObjectID=5698942&lid=1 Francis Towne "The West Front of Tintern Abbey, Monmouthshire", at Christies] Accessed 9 October 2017</ref> [[Thomas Gainsborough]] (1782),<ref>[http://www.tate.org.uk/art/artworks/gainsborough-tintern-abbey-t08906 Thomas Gainsborough: "Tintern Abbey" 1782, at Tate Gallery] Accessed 9 October 2017</ref> [[Thomas Girtin]] (1793),<ref>[https://www.artrenewal.org/pages/artwork.php?artworkid=28968 Thomas Girtin: "Interior of Tintern Abbey looking toward the West Window", at Art Renewal Center] Accessed 9 October 2017</ref> and [[J.M.W. Turner]] in the 1794–95 series now at the [[Tate]]<ref>[http://www.iconeye.com/images/2014/05/turner_tinternabbey_1_rt.jpg J.M.W. Turner: "Tintern Abbey: The Crossing and Chancel, Looking towards the East Window" (detail) at Iconeye] Accessed 9 October 2017</ref> and the [[British Museum]], depicted details of the Abbey's stonework.<ref>[https://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pd/j/jmw_turner,_tintern_abbey.aspx BM site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151018213750/http://www.britishmuseum.org/explore/highlights/highlight_objects/pd/j/jmw_turner,_tintern_abbey.aspx |date=2015-10-18 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=743765&partId=1&place=38910&plaA=38910-1-4&page=1 J.M.W. Turner: Tintern Abbey, west front; the ruined abbey, overgrown with grass and bushes... British Museum, Collection online] Accessed 14 October 2017</ref> So did [[Samuel Palmer]] (see Gallery) and [[Thomas Creswick]] in the 19th century.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/arts/yourpaintings/paintings/part-of-the-ruins-of-tintern-abbey-21775 BBC Arts] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150716021002/http://www.bbc.co.uk/arts/yourpaintings/paintings/part-of-the-ruins-of-tintern-abbey-21775 |date=2015-07-16 }}</ref><ref>[https://artuk.org/discover/artworks/part-of-the-ruins-of-tintern-abbey-21775/search/keyword:thomas-creswick-tintern Thomas Creswick (1811–1869) "Part of the Ruins of Tintern Abbey" Calderdale Metropolitan Borough Council, at artuk.org] Accessed 14 October 2017</ref>
Charles Heath, in his 1793 guide, commented on the picturesque quality of light in the "inimitable" effect of the [[harvest moon]] shining through the main window.<ref>Charles Heath, ''Historical and Descriptive Accounts of the Ancient and Present State of Tintern Abbey'', Monmouth, [http://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=hvd.hxjped;view=1up;seq=91 p.91]</ref> Once the railway arrived in 1876, steam excursions to the site were organised in the 1880s to [[Tintern railway station|Tintern station]] at that season to view the moon through the rose window.<ref>[http://overlookingthewye.org.uk/index.php/hidden-industry/old-station/old-station-history Wye Valley, Old Station Tintern - history, at overlookingthewye.org.uk] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref> Decades earlier, Peter van Lerberghe’s interior of 1812, with its tourist guides<ref>C.S.Matheson, "I wanted some intelligent guide", ''Romanticism'', [http://www.euppublishing.com/doi/abs/10.3366/rom.2013.0127 p.38]</ref> carrying burning torches, showed the abbey lit by these and by moonlight (see Gallery). Paintings of the abbey at a distance include [[John Warwick Smith]]’s 1779 moonlit scene of the ruins,<ref>[http://images.metmuseum.org/CRDImages/dp/web-large/DP805068.jpg John Warwick Smith - moonlit scene of the ruins - at the Metropolitan Museum] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref> sunsets by Samuel Palmer<ref>[https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Samuel_Palmer_-_Tintern_Abbey_at_Sunset_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg Samuel Palmer - "Tintern Abbey at Sunset" at Wikimedia] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref> and [[Benjamin Williams Leader]],<ref>[https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/40/Benjamin_Williams_Leader_Tintern_Abbey.jpg Benjamin Williams Leader "Tintern Abbey" at Wikimedia] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref> and the later colour study by Turner in which the building appears as what Matthew Imms describes as a "dark shape at the centre" beneath slanting sunlight (see Gallery).<ref>[https://www.tate.org.uk/art/research-publications/jmw-turner/joseph-mallord-william-turner-tintern-abbey-from-the-river-wye-r1144329 Matthew Imms, "Tintern Abbey from the River Wye c.1828 by Joseph Mallord William Turner", catalogue entry, March 2013, in David Blayney Brown (ed.), ''J.M.W. Turner: Sketchbooks, Drawings and Watercolours'', Tate Research Publication, December 2013] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref><ref>Sandra Gibson, review of the 2012 Turner, Monet, Twombly exhibition at Tate Liverpool, [http://www.catalystmedia.org.uk/reviews/turner_monet_twombly.php Catalyst Media]</ref>
==Industry and access== The area adjacent to the abbey became industrialised from the mid-16th century with the setting up of the first wireworks by the [[Company of Mineral and Battery Works]] and the later expansion of factories and furnaces up the Angidy valley. Charcoal was made in the woods to feed these operations and, in addition, the hillside above the Abbey was quarried for the making of lime at a kiln in constant operation for some two centuries.<ref>[http://www.wyedeantourism.co.uk/general_cache1 Wye-Dean Tourism (exact ref not found)] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref> The site was in consequence subject to a degree of pollution<ref>Charles J. Rzepka, ''Inventions and Interventions'', [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=kVqe8edkKscC&pg=PA193&lpg=PA193&dq=tintern+abbey++industry&source=bl&ots=4e93c9snm7&sig=QkJTjb_4YKN5lP_W7BxqddUrkCc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CE4Q6AEwCWoVChMI14Kv8YjvyAIVi7gUCh1weAOp#v=onepage&q=tintern%20abbey%20%20industry&f=false ch.14, pp.189–222]</ref> and the ruins themselves were inhabited by the local workers. [[John Thomas Barber Beaumont|J.T.Barber]], for example, remarked on “passing the works of an iron foundry and a train of miserable cottages engrafted on the offices of the Abbey” on his approach.<ref>.” J.T.Barber, A tour throughout South Wales and Monmouthshire, London 1803 [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9dcuAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=%22passing%20the%20works%22&f=false p.266]</ref>
[[File:Tintern Wire Works Bridge.JPG|thumb|upright=1.2|The WVR branch line bridge to the wire works]] Until the 19th century, the local roads were rough and dangerous and the easiest access to the site was by boat. [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]], while trying to reach Tintern from Chepstow on a tour with friends in 1795, almost rode his horse over the edge of a quarry when they became lost in the dark.<ref>Joseph Cottle, ''Early recollections: chiefly relating to the late Samuel Taylor Coleridge'', London 1837, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=GydEAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA42&lpg=PA42&dq=%22being+an+indifferent+walker+%28from+a+former+dislocation%22&source=bl&ots=P28lmz042H&sig=ACX3wMF9aopcszod7eK9NqxQ0VM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAWoVChMIsuvFu_nuyAIVwUAUCh2J7AYM#v=onepage&q=%22being%20an%20indifferent%20walker%20%28from%20a%20former%20dislocation%22&f=false pp.43–50]</ref> It was not until 1829 that the new Wye Valley turnpike was completed, cutting through the abbey precinct.<ref>Cadw, [http://www.ggat.org.uk/cadw/historic_landscape/wye_valley/english/wyevalley_013.htm Lower Wye Valley]</ref> In 1876 the [[Wye Valley Railway]] opened a station for Tintern. Although the line itself crossed the river before reaching the village, a [[Tintern Wireworks Branch|branch]] was built from it to the wire works, obstructing the view of the Abbey on the road approach from the north.
Not all tourists were shocked by the intrusion of industry, however. [[Joseph Cottle]] and [[Robert Southey]] set out to view the ironworks at midnight on their 1795 tour,<ref>Joseph Cottle, ''Early Recollections'' pp.50–1</ref> while others painted or sketched them during the following years.<ref>See the 1798 print of “Iron Mills, A View near Tintern Abbey" belonging to [http://search.digido.org.uk/?id=llgc-id%3a1133291&query=*&query_type=full_text&page=1&qf=subject_lctgm_topic%3aFoundries the National Library of Wales] and James Ward’s 1807 sketch of “Mr Thompson’s Wire Mill, Tintern” at the [http://www.centerforbritishart.org/art-in-focus-wales/182/mr-thompsons-wire-mill-tintern Yale Center for British Art]</ref> A 1799 print of the Abbey by [[Edward Dayes]] includes the boat-landing near the ruins and some of the encroaching housing. In the background above are the cliffs of a lime quarry and smoke rising from the kiln (see the Gallery). Though [[Philip James de Loutherbourg]]’s 1805 painting of the ruins does not include the intrusive buildings commented on by others, it makes their inhabitants and animals a prominent feature. Even [[William Havell]]’s panorama of the valley from the south pictures smoke rising in the distance, much as Wordsworth had noted five years before “wreathes of smoke sent up in silence from among the trees” in his description of the scene.<ref>”Lines written a few miles above Tintern Abbey”, lines 18–19</ref>
==Heritage== In the 20th century ruined abbeys became the focus for scholars, and architectural and archaeological investigations were undertaken. In 1901 the Abbey was bought by the crown from the [[Henry Somerset, 9th Duke of Beaufort|Duke of Beaufort]] for £15,000. It was recognised as a monument of national importance and repair and maintenance works began to be carried out. In 1914 the [[Office of Works]] was passed responsibility for the ruins, and major structural repairs and partial reconstructions were undertaken — the [[ivy]] considered so romantic by the early tourists was removed. In 1984 [[Cadw]] took over responsibility for the site, which was [[Grade I]] listed from 29 September 2000.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/wa-24037-abbey-church-of-st-mary-tintern-abbey-inc |title=Abbey Church of St Mary (Tintern Abbey) including monastic buildings – Tintern – Monmouthshire – Wales |publisher=British Listed Buildings |date= |accessdate=2013-06-03}}</ref> The arch of the Abbey's watergate, which led from the Abbey to the River Wye, still exists today as part of the nearby Anchor Inn.<ref>{{cite web|author=fotolibra.com (showing the Abbey watergate attached to the Anchor Inn) |url=http://www.fotolibra.com/gallery/1169001/the-anchor-inn-tintern-wye-valley-wales/ |title=The Anchor Inn Tintern Wye Valley Wales |publisher=Fotolibra |date= |accessdate=23 Nov 2017}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|author=visitmonmouthshire.com (mentions the Abbey watergate) |url=https://www.visitmonmouthshire.com/thedms.aspx?dms=3&venue=1250480 |title=The Anchor Inn |publisher=Visit Monmouthshire |date= |accessdate=23 Nov 2017}}</ref> The watergate arch was also [[Grade II]] listed from 29 September 2000.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.britishlistedbuildings.co.uk/wa-24032-the-anchor-p-h-including-the-watergate-ti#.WLjsUDsrI2x |title=The Anchor P H including the Watergate, Tintern |publisher=British Listed Buildings |date= |accessdate=2017-03-02}}</ref>
American poet [[Allen Ginsberg]] took an [[LSD|acid]] trip at Tintern Abbey on 28 July 1967, and wrote his poem "Wales Visitation" as a result. In the poem he wrote of:<ref>Ginsberg: A biography by Barry Miles, Virgin Publishing 2000 p394</ref><ref>[http://teifidancer-teifidancer.blogspot.com/2010/01/allen-ginsbergs-wales-visitation.html Allan Ginsburg's 'Wales Visitation'] 2010-01-31, accessed 2012-01-01</ref> <blockquote><poem> ...the lambs on the tree-nooked hillside this day bleating heard in Blake's old ear, & the silent thought of Wordsworth in eld Stillness clouds passing through skeleton arches of Tintern Abbey— Bard Nameless as the Vast, babble to Vastness!</poem></blockquote>
The Abbey is the setting for both the 1969 [[The Flirtations (R&B musical group)|Flirtations]] music video ''[[Nothing But A Heartache]]''<ref>[http://www.songfacts.com/detail.php?id=13568 "Nothing But A Heartache" by The Flirtations at Song Facts] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref> and the 1988 [[Iron Maiden]] video ''[[Can I Play with Madness]]''.
Gordon Masters' historical novel ''The Secrets of Tintern Abbey'' (2008) dramatises the turbulent 400-year history of the Cistercian community at the Abbey.<ref>[https://books.google.ca/books?id=KJez44FPnk8C Gordon Masters, ''The Secrets of Tintern Abbey: A Historical Novel'', Wheatmark, 2008] Accessed 7 October 2017</ref>

In [[archaeology]] a '''typology''' is the result of the [[Categorization|classification]] of things according to their physical characteristics. The products of the classification, i.e. the classes, are also called types. Most archaeological typologies organize portable [[Artifact (archaeology)|artifacts]] into types, but typologies of larger structures, including buildings, [[Ancient monument|field monuments]], [[fortification]]s or roads, are equally possible. A typology helps to manage a large mass of archaeological data. According to Doran and Hodson, "this superficially straightforward task has proved one of the most time consuming and contentious aspects of archaeological research".<ref>{{cite book |last1=Doran |first1=J.E. |last2=Hodson |first2=F.R. |year=1975 |title=Mathematics and Computers in Archaeology |place=Edinburgh |publisher=Edinburgh University Press |ISBN=0-85224-250-6 |page=158 }}</ref>
==Philosophical background== Typology is based on a view of the world familiar from [[Plato]]'s [[metaphysics]] called [[essentialism]]. Essentialism is the idea that the world is divided into real, discontinuous and immutable ‘kinds’. This idea is the basis for most typological constructions, particularly of stone artefacts where essential forms are often thought of as ‘mental templates’, or combinations of traits that are favoured by the maker. Variation in artifact form and attributes is seen as a consequence of the imperfect realization of the template, and is usually attributed to differences in raw material properties or individuals' technical competences.
==History== Although the principles were not clearly articulated, the application of basic typological techniques can occasionally be found in the work of [[Early modern period|early modern]] [[Antiquarian|antiquaries]]. As early as the 1530s, [[John Leland (antiquary)|John Leland]] successfully identified [[Roman brick]]s (under the misleading designation "Briton brykes") at several different sites, distinguishing them from more modern bricks by size and shape.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Harris |first=Oliver |title=John Leland and the 'Briton Brykes' |journal=Antiquaries Journal |volume=87 |year=2007 |pages=346–56 |doi=10.1017/s0003581500000949}}</ref> Antiquaries began to recognise in the late 16th century that medieval [[English church monuments|monumental effigies]] represented with their legs crossed were likely to be older than those with straight legs.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Harris |first=O.D. |title=Antiquarian attitudes: crossed legs, crusaders and the evolution of an idea |journal=Antiquaries Journal |volume=90 |year=2010 |pages=401–40 |doi=10.1017/s0003581510000053}}</ref> In the late 17th century, [[John Aubrey]] worked out crude evolutionary sequences based on typological distinctions for medieval architecture, handwriting, shield-shapes and costume.<ref>{{cite book |last=Hunter |first=Michael |title=John Aubrey and the Realm of Learning |place=London |year=1975 |pages=156–7, 162–6, 181 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Colvin |first=H.M. |chapter=Aubrey’s 'Chronologia Architectonica' |editor-first=John |editor-last=Summerson |title=Concerning Architecture |place=London |year=1968 |pages=1–12 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |first=Olivia |last=Horsfall Turner |authorlink=Olivia Horsfall Turner |title='The Windows of this Church are of several Fashions': architectural form and historical method in John Aubrey's 'Chronologia Architectonica'|journal=Architectural History |volume=54 |year=2011 |pages=171–93 }}</ref> The outline of the development of medieval [[Gothic architecture]] was further refined in the 18th century, culminating in the clear sequence of styles published by [[Thomas Rickman]] in 1817.<ref>{{cite book |last=Frankl |first=P. |title=The Gothic: literary sources and interpretations through eight centuries |place=Princeton |year=1960 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Watkin |first=D. |title=The Rise of Architectural History |place=London |year=1980 |pages=53–9}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Roberts |first=M. |title=Thomas Gray’s contribution to the study of medieval architecture |journal=Architectural History |volume=36 |year=1993 |pages=49–68}}</ref>
In the 19th and early 20th centuries archaeological typologies continued to be constructed using a combination of empirical observation and intuition. According to Eggers,<ref>{{cite book |last=Eggers |first=Hans-Jürgen |year=1986 |title=Einführung in die Vorgeschichte |place=München |publisher=Piper Verlag |pages=88–95 |ISBN=3-492-00393-1 }}</ref> most archaeologists give [[Oscar Montelius]] the credit for the first serious application of the typological method, but in Eggers' view, his contemporary colleague from Stockholm, Hans Hildebrand made important contributions to the development of the methodology as well. Hildebrand published a fundamental paper on the development of [[fibulae]] in the 1870s using the typological method, whereas Montelius at the same time went to international congresses and published smaller papers on this method.
Another early example is the typology published in 1899 by [[Flinders Petrie]] for the objects (mainly pottery) found in 900 prehistoric Egyptian graves.<ref>{{cite book |last=Kendall |first=D.G. |year=1971 |chapter=Seriation from abundance matrices |title=Mathematics in the Archaeological and Historical Sciences |editor1-first=F.R. |editor1-last=Hodson |editor2-first=D.G. |editor2-last=Kendall |editor3-first=P. |editor3-last=Tautu |pages=215–252 |place=Edinburgh |publisher=Edinburgh University Press |ISBN=0-85224-213-1 }}</ref> This typology formed the basis for his manual [[Seriation (archaeology)|seriation]] of the graves.
==Statistical methods for creating a typology== With the development of [[statistics|statistical]] techniques and numerical [[Taxonomy (general)|taxonomy]] in the 1960s, mathematical methods (including [[Cluster analysis]], [[Principal components analysis]], [[correspondence analysis]] and [[Factor analysis]]) have been used to build typologies. These techniques provide a qualitative way to articulate the degrees of consistency among particular attributes. Correlation coefficients created by these methods help archaeologists discern between meaningful and useless similarities between artefacts.<ref>{{cite book|author=Spaulding, Albert C|title=Statistical Techniques for the Discovery of Artifact Types|date=1953|publisher=American Antiquity|volume=18}}</ref> During the 1990s [[archaeologist]]s began to use [[phylogenetic]] methods borrowed from [[Cladistics]].
==Ceramic typology== For cultures that produced pottery, archaeologists invariably spend a great deal of time defining ceramic "types." Each type is a series of attributes which distinguishes one group of pottery (whether whole vessels or potsherds) from all other groups of pottery, such that each type was produced in a single time and place. Ideally, the attributes used to identify types are ones that are identifiable with the naked eye, and are found on small fragments of pottery, so that the sorting of potsherds into types is quick and straightforward. By sorting potsherds in terms of types, archaeologists can examine a series of potsherds (including those lying on a site surface) and quickly suggest when and where the pottery was made. By extension, they can estimate when a prehistoric site was used, whether there are any traded pieces, and so on.
The names assigned to the ceramic types are arbitrary. In United States, the common practice is a two-part name, the first part being an arbitrary geographic reference and the second part providing a brief description of the pottery's most obvious design attributes. Thus, for example, the type "Flagstaff Black-on-white" was first defined using a collection from the vicinity of Flagstaff, Arizona, and its primary design attribute is the use of black paint on a white background.
Non-archaeologists should be aware of the limitations of ceramic typology. All such typologies are abstractions, and fail to describe all of the variability in an artistic tradition. Professional disagreement over specifics is common. Changes in ceramic design did not happen overnight, and archaeological typologies tend to break continua of design evolution into arbitrary (but highly useful) units. Most archaeological dates are approximate.
==Non-archaeological typology as an art form== In the middle of the twentieth century, German photographers [[Bernd and Hilla Becher]]<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/dp/026202277X Bernd and Hilla Becher, ''Water Towers'', The MIT Press, 1988]</ref> raised typology to an art form by photographing countless similar architectural features including water towers, workers' houses and industrial landscapes. They documented their work in books.
== Types of typologies == ''There are four main types of typologies that archaeologists organize artifacts into.''
=== Morphological/descriptive typology === One class of typology consists of a descriptive or [http://www.archaeologywordsmith.com/lookup.php?terms=typology a morphological] approach. It is based on the physical characteristics and the external features of an artifact. Some examples of morphological and descriptive typologies would be categorizing artifacts distinctively on their weight, height, color, material, or whichever class the individual decides upon.
==== Projectile point typology ==== An example of morphological/descriptive typology consists of when an archaeologist excavates a site and finds dozens upon dozens of Native American arrowheads. The archaeologist narrows down their classification by organizing the pieces into morphological/descriptive groups. So, the [[projectile point]]s could be sorted by weight, height, color, material, or however the archaeologists prefers. One of the first national typology bases available on the web, [http://www.projectilepoints.net/Search/Search.html The Projectile Points Typology Database] , exhibits how the arrowhead artifacts found are classified among the fifty states by region, state, or nationwide.
In this particular example, the arrowheads are classified by their shape. The categories consist of: notched, stemmed, lanceolate, and other projectile points. Each category may also be narrowed down into subsequent ones. [[File:ProjPointTerm.jpg|thumb|An example of morphological/descriptive typology. Archaeologist classified these arrowheads based on the projectile point shape.]]
=== Chronological typology === This type consists of sequential ordering of archaeological artifacts merely based on form. It involves collecting dates or relative dates that establishes the position in time the artifact lies in to reflect the civilization/events of a current region <ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.archaeologywordsmith.com/lookup.php?terms=typology|title = Archaeology Wordsmith|website = www.archaeologywordsmith.com|access-date = 2016-03-09}}</ref> A [[Chronology|chronological]] typology is made up of diagnostic artifacts, or relics that suggests a particular event/people occurred during a period of time <ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.wvculture.org/shpo/glossary.html|title = Glossary of Archaeology Terms|website = www.wvculture.org|access-date = 2016-03-09}}</ref> See [https://www.jefpat.org/diagnostic/Post-Colonial%20Ceramics/PaintedWares/index-paintedwares.htm underglaze painted earthenwares] for an example of chronological typology.
=== Functional typology === Artifacts organized into this kind of typology are sorted by the use they serve rather than the looks they have or the chronological sequence they possess. In some cases, the artifacts may not be removed because of the functional purpose they exhibit, and the restoration of the pieces can be more difficult than other types of objects <ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.venipedia.org/wiki/index.php?title=Functional_Artifacts|title = Functional Artifacts - Venipedia|website = www.venipedia.org|access-date = 2016-03-09}}</ref>
=== Stylistic typology === This type of classification displays information about the artifact via the object's display. Stylistic typology is not to be confused with classification of certain styles, for that would just entail organizing artifacts based on how they look. This type of typology accounts for information told through the artifact. [[Pottery]] is an example of a stylistic typology because the artifacts provide information on artistic evolution.<ref>{{Cite book|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=abDhtdHFyCkC|title = Archaeological Typology and Practical Reality: A Dialectical Approach to Artifact Classification and Sorting|last = Adams|first = William Y.|last2 = Adams|first2 = Ernest W.|date = 2007-11-26|publisher = Cambridge University Press|isbn = 9780521048675|language = en}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=January 2014}} The '''unitary executive theory''' is a theory of [[United States Constitution|American constitutional law]] holding that the [[President of the United States|President]] possesses the power to control the entire executive branch. The doctrine is rooted in [[Article Two of the United States Constitution]], which vests "the executive power" of the United States in the President. Although that general principle is widely accepted, there is disagreement about the strength and scope of the doctrine. It can be said that some favor a "strongly unitary" executive, while others favor a "weakly unitary" executive. The former group argue, for example, that [[United States Congress|Congress]]'s power to interfere with intra-executive decision-making (such as firing executive branch officials) is limited, and that the President can control policy-making by all executive agencies within the limits set for those agencies by Congress. Still others agree that the Constitution requires a unitary executive, but believe this to be harmful, and propose its abolition by [[Constitutional amendment#United States|constitutional amendment]]. {{anchor|Plural executive}}'''Plural executives''' exist in several [[U.S. state|states]] where, in contrast to the federal government, executive officers such as [[Lieutenant governor (United States)|lieutenant governor]], [[State attorney general|attorney general]], [[comptroller#United States|comptroller]], [[Secretary of State (U.S. state government)|secretary of state]], and others, are elected independently of the [[Governor (United States)|state's governor]], with [[Texas#State government|Texas]] being one example. This type of executive structure is known as a plural executive. Another type of plural executive, used in Japan, Israel, and Sweden, though not in any U.S. state, in which a collegial body comprises the executive branch – however, that collegial body does not comprise multiple members elected in elections, but is rather more akin to the [[U.S. Cabinet]] in formation and structure. ==Theory== The [[Vesting Clause]] of [[Article Two of the United States Constitution|Article II]] provides, "The executive Power [of the United States] shall be vested in a President of the United States of America." Proponents of the unitary executive theory argue that this language, along with the [[Take Care Clause]] ("The President shall take care that the laws be faithfully executed..."), creates a "hierarchical, unified executive department under the direct control of the President."{{cite journal |last1= Calabresi |first1= Steven |last2= Rhodes |first2= Kevin |lastauthoramp= yes |title= The Structural Constitution: Unitary Executive, Plural Judiciary |journal= Harvard Law Review |year= 1992 |volume= 105 |issue= 6 |page= 1165 |doi=10.2307/1341727 |jstor= 1341727 }} The general principle that the President controls the entire executive branch was originally rather innocuous, but extreme forms of the theory have developed. [[John Dean]] explains: "In its most extreme form, unitary executive theory can mean that neither Congress nor the federal courts can tell the President what to do or how to do it, particularly regarding national security matters."{{cite book |last= Dean |first= John |url= https://books.google.com/?id=dj56j5TsNUAC&pg=PA102&dq=%22unitary+executive%22#PPA102,M1 |title= Broken Government |page= 102 |publisher= Viking |year= 2007|isbn= 9780670018208 }} According to law professors [[Lawrence Lessig]] and [[Cass Sunstein]], "No one denies that in some sense the framers created a unitary executive; the question is in what sense. Let us distinguish between a strong and a weak version."{{cite journal |last1= Lessig |first1= Lawrence |last2= Sunstein |first2= Cass |lastauthoramp= yes |url= http://www.pegc.us/archive/Authorities/Lessig_Col_L_R_President.pdf |format= PDF |title= The President and the Administration |journal= [[Columbia Law Review]] |volume= 94 |year= 1994}} In either its strong or weak form, the theory would limit the power of Congress to divest the President of control of the executive branch. The "strongly unitary" theory posits stricter limits on Congress than the "weakly unitary" theory. Some scholars oppose even the "weakly unitary" theory and favor creating a plural executive, as in the many state governments that separately elect an attorney general.{{cite journal |last1= Berry |first1= Christopher |last2= Gersen |first2= Jacob |lastauthoramp= yes |url= http://law.bepress.com/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1057&context=nwwps |title= The Unbundled Executive |journal= University of Chicago Law Review |year= 2008 |quote= We certainly do not claim that the most sensible or even any plausible interpretation of the US Constitution establishes a plural unbundled executive; but perhaps it should |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110807190941/http://law.bepress.com/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1057&context=nwwps |archivedate= August 7, 2011 |df= mdy-all }} However, those scholars acknowledge that a constitutional amendment would be required to eliminate the federal unitary executive. Proponents of a strongly unitary theory argue that the president possesses ''all'' of the executive power and can therefore control subordinate officers and agencies of the executive branch. This implies that the power of Congress to remove executive agencies or officers from Presidential control is limited. Thus, under the strongly unitary executive theory, independent agencies and counsels are unconstitutional to the extent that they exercise discretionary executive power not controlled by the president. The [[Federal government of the United States#Judicial branch|judicial branch]] implications are that a part of the executive branch cannot [[lawsuit|sue]] another part because "the executive cannot sue himself." If the [[United States federal courts|federal courts]] were to adjudicate disputes between [[List of United States federal agencies|executive agencies]], it would violate the doctrine of [[separation of powers]].{{cite journal |last= Latham |first= Joshua |url= http://www.bc.edu/schools/law/lawreviews/meta-elements/journals/bcealr/27_3/04_FMS.htm |title= The Military Munitions Rule and Environmental Regulation of Munitions |journal= Boston College Environmental Affairs Law Review |volume= 27 |page= 467 |year=2000}} ==Adoption of constitutional provisions== The phrase "unitary executive" was discussed as early as the [[Philadelphia Convention]] in 1787, referring mainly to having a single individual fill the office of President, as proposed in the [[Virginia Plan]]. The alternative was to have several executives or an executive council, as proposed in the [[New Jersey Plan]] and as promoted by [[Elbridge Gerry]], [[Edmund Randolph]], and [[George Mason]].{{cite book |editor-first= Ralph |editor-last= Ketchum |title= The Anti-Federalist Papers and the Constitutional Convention Debates |publisher= Signet Classic |year= 1986 |page= 67 |quote= Mr. [James] Wilson entered into a contrast of the principal points of the two plans [i.e. the Virginia Plan and the New Jersey Plan]... These were... A single Executive Magistrate is at the head of the one—a plurality is held out in the other.}}{{cite web |url= http://press-pubs.uchicago.edu/founders/documents/a2_1_1s4.html |title= Records of the Federal Convention, Article 2, Section 1, Clause 1 |year= 1787 |work= The Founder’s Constitution}} At the Pennsylvania ratifying convention in 1787, [[James Wilson]] emphasized the advantages of a single chief executive, including greater accountability, vigor, decisiveness, and responsibility:
[T]he executive authority is one. By this means we obtain very important advantages. We may discover from history, from reason, and from experience, the security which this furnishes. The executive power is better to be trusted when it has no screen. Sir, we have a responsibility in the person of our President; he cannot act improperly, and hide either his negligence or inattention; he cannot roll upon any other person the weight of his criminality; no appointment can take place without his nomination; and he is responsible for every nomination he makes. We secure vigor. We well know what numerous executives are. We know there is neither vigor, decision, nor responsibility, in them. Add to all this, that officer is placed high, and is possessed of power far from being contemptible; yet not a single privilege is annexed to his character; far from being above the laws, he is amenable to them in his private character as a citizen, and in his public character by impeachment.{{cite web |last= Wilson |first= James |url= http://press-pubs.uchicago.edu/founders/documents/a2_1_1s8.html |title= Pennsylvania Ratifying Convention |date= December 4, 1787}}
In 1788, the letters of the [[Federal Farmer]] were published, generally considered among the most astute of [[Anti-Federalist]] writings. The [[pseudonym]]ous Federal Farmer defended the proposed unitary executive, arguing that "a single man seems to be peculiarly well circumstanced to superintend the execution of laws with discernment and decision, with promptitude and uniformity."{{cite book |last= Ellis |first= Richard |url= https://books.google.com/?id=ybmeEcpEvlsC&pg=PA39&dq=%22superintend+the+execution+of+laws+with+discernment+and+decision%22 |title= Founding the American Presidency |page= 39 |publisher= Rowman & Littlefield |year= 1999|isbn= 9780847694990 }} Meanwhile, [[Federalists]] such as [[James Madison]] were emphasizing an additional advantage of a unitary executive. In [[Federalist No. 51]], he wrote that an undivided executive would strengthen the ability of the executive to resist encroachments by the legislature: “As the weight of the legislative authority requires that it should be thus divided [into branches], the weakness of the executive may require, on the other hand, that it should be fortified.”{{cite web |last= Madison |first= James |url= http://www.constitution.org/fed/federa51.htm |title= Federalist no. 51 |date= February 6, 1788}} [[Alexander Hamilton]] later pointed out that the Constitution grants executive power and legislative power in different ways, with the legislative powers of Congress being expressly limited to what is "herein granted," unlike executive powers which are not expressly limited by an enumeration. Hamilton wrote:
In the article which gives the legislative powers of the government, the expressions are "All legislative powers herein granted shall be vested in a congress of the United States." In that which grants the executive power, the expressions are "The executive power shall be vested in a President of the United States." The enumeration ought therefore to be considered, as intended merely to specify the principal articles implied in the definition of executive power....{{cite web |last= Hamilton |first= Alexander |url= http://www.humanitiesweb.org/human.php?s=h&p=c&a=p&ID=27786&c=748 |title= Pacificus Letters, No. 1 |date= June 29, 1793}}
In other words, the principle of ''[[Statutory_interpretation#Textual|expressio unius]]'' may be more applicable as a limitation upon congressional power than upon executive power. According to Hamilton, the unenumerated executive powers that are vested solely in the President "flow from the general grant of that power, interpreted in conformity with other parts of the Constitution, and with the principles of free government." Those other parts of the Constitution include the extensive powers granted to Congress. Article I of the Constitution gives Congress the exclusive power to make laws, which the President then must execute, provided that those laws are constitutional. Article I, Section 8, clause 18 of the Constitution known as the [[Necessary and Proper Clause]] grants Congress the power to "make all Laws which shall be necessary and proper for carrying into Execution all Powers vested by this Constitution in the Government of the United States, or in any Department or Officer thereof". The Constitution also [[Article One of the United States Constitution#Enumerated powers|grants Congress power]] "To make Rules for the Government and Regulation of the land and naval Forces." The theory of the unitary executive can only be legitimate insofar as it allows Congress to wield its constitutional powers while ensuring that the President can do the same. ==Judicial decisions== In the 1926 case of ''[[Myers v. United States]]'', the United States Supreme Court decided that the President has the exclusive power to remove executive branch officials, and does not need the approval of the Senate or any other legislative body. The Court also wrote:
The ordinary duties of officers prescribed by statute come under the general administrative control of the President by virtue of the general grant to him of the executive power, and he may properly supervise and guide their construction of the statutes under which they act in order to secure that unitary and uniform execution of the laws which article 2 of the Constitution evidently contemplated in vesting general executive power in the President alone.{{cite court |litigants= Myers v. United States |vol= 272 |reporter= U.S. |opinion= 52 |pinpoint= |court= |date= 1926 |url= http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/scripts/getcase.pl?navby=CASE&court=US&vol=272&page=52 }}
Subsequent cases such as ''[[Humphrey's Executor v. United States]]'' (Presidential removal of certain kinds of officers), ''[[United States v. Nixon]]'' (executive privilege), and ''[[Bowsher v. Synar]]'' (control of executive functions) have flexed the doctrine's reach back and forth. [[Antonin Scalia|Justice Scalia]] in his solitary dissent in ''[[Morrison v. Olson]]'' argued for an unlimited presidential removal power of all persons exercising executive branch powers, which he argued included the [[independent counsel]]; the court disagreed, but later moved closer to Scalia's position in ''[[Edmond v. United States]]''.{{cite journal |last1= Calabresi |first1= Steven |last2= Lawson |first2= Gary |lastauthoramp= yes |url= http://www.columbialawreview.org/assets/pdfs/107/4/Calabresi-Lawson.pdf |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20090306120412/http://www.columbialawreview.org/assets/pdfs/107/4/Calabresi-Lawson.pdf |dead-url= yes |archive-date= 2009-03-06 |format= PDF |title= The Unitary Executive, Jurisdiction Stripping, and the Hamdan Opinions: A Textualist Response to Justice Scalia |journal= Columbia Law Review |year= 2007 |volume= 107 |pages= 1002–1047}} ==Criticism of the strong version of the theory== [[Loyola Law School]] Professors [[Karl Manheim]] and [[Allan Ides]] write that "the separation among the branches is not and never was intended to be airtight," and they point to the President's veto power as an example of the executive exercising legislative power. They also cite other examples of quasi-legislative and quasi-judicial power being exercised by the executive branch, as necessary elements of the administrative state, but they contend that ultimately all administrative power belongs to Congress rather than the President, and the only true "executive" powers are those explicitly described in the Constitution.{{cite journal |last1=Manheim |first1=Karl |last2=Ides |first2=Allan |lastauthoramp=yes |ssrn=943046 |title=The Unitary Executive |journal=Los Angeles Lawyer |date=September 2006 |id=Loyola-LA Legal Studies Paper No. 2006-39}} In this understanding, Manheim and Ides follow in the footsteps of Lessig and Sunstein. Professors [[David Jeremiah Barron]] and [[Marty Lederman]] have also criticized the strong version of the unitary executive theory. They acknowledge that there is a compelling case for a unitary executive within the armed forces.{{cite journal |last1=Barron |first1=David |last2=Lederman |first2=Martin |lastauthoramp=yes |url=http://www.harvardlawreview.org/issues/121/jan08/barron_lederman.shtml |title=The Commander In Chief At The Lowest Ebb: Framing The Problem, Doctrine, And Original Understanding |journal=[[Harvard Law Review]] |volume=121 |page=689 |year=2008 |quote=we think the text, as reinforced by historical practice, makes a strong case for at least some form of a 'unitary executive' within the armed forces, particularly as to traditional functions during armed conflicts. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090125114946/http://harvardlawreview.org/issues/121/jan08/barron_lederman.shtml |archivedate=January 25, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} However, they argue that the Constitution does not provide for an equally strong unitary executive outside the military context, and they argue that the [[Article Two of the United States Constitution#Clause 1: Command of military; Opinions of cabinet secretaries; Pardons|Commander in Chief Clause]] would be superfluous if the same kind of unitary presidential authority resulted from the general constitutional provision vesting executive power in the President.{{cite journal |last1=Barron |first1=David |last2=Lederman |first2=Martin |lastauthoramp=yes |url=http://www.harvardlawreview.org/issues/121/feb08/barron_lederman2.shtml |title=The Commander in Chief at the Lowest Ebb: A Constitutional History |journal=Harvard Law Review |volume=121 |page=941 |year=2008 |quote=there are those who would argue that the 'unitary executive' must have effective control over all Article II functions, in which case the superintendence guaranteed by the Commander in Chief Clause would not appear to do any additional work with respect to superintendence. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090124223310/http://harvardlawreview.org/issues/121/feb08/barron_lederman2.shtml |archivedate=January 24, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} Contrary to claims of some authors,{{cite conference |last=Kelley |first=Christopher |url=http://www.users.muohio.edu/kelleycs/paper.pdf |format=PDF |title=Rethinking Presidential Power: The Unitary Executive and the George W. Bush Presidency |conference=63rd Annual Meeting of the [[Midwest Political Science Association]] |date=April 7–10, 2005 |location=Chicago }} the first administration to make explicit reference to the "Unitary Executive" was not that of President [[George W. Bush]]. For example, in 1987, [[Ronald Reagan]] issued a [[signing statement]] that declared: "If this provision were interpreted otherwise, so as to require the President to follow the orders of a subordinate, it would plainly constitute an unconstitutional infringement of the President's authority as head of a unitary executive branch."{{cite web |last=Reagan |first=Ronald |url=http://www.reagan.utexas.edu/archives/speeches/1987/092987d.htm |title=Statement on Signing the Federal Debt Limit and Deficit Reduction Bill |date=September 29, 1987}} The George W. Bush administration made the Unitary Executive Theory a common feature of signing statements.{{cite journal |authorlink=Dawn Johnsen |last=Johnsen |first=Dawn |url=http://www.bu.edu/law/central/jd/organizations/journals/bulr/documents/JOHNSEN.pdf |format=PDF |title=What's a President To Do? Interpreting the Constitution in the Wake of Bush Administration Abuses |journal=Boston University Law Review |volume=88 |page=395 |date=April 2008 |quote=On 363 occasions, President Bush objected to provisions that he found might conflict with the president’s constitutional authority 'to supervise the unitary executive branch.'}} For example, Bush once wrote in a signing statement that he would, "construe Title X in Division A of the Act, relating to detainees, in a manner consistent with the constitutional authority of the President to supervise the unitary executive branch and as Commander in Chief and consistent with the constitutional limitations on the judicial power."{{cite news |last=Lazarus |first=Edward |url=http://writ.news.findlaw.com/lazarus/20060105.html |title=How Much Authority Does the President Possess When He Is Acting as 'Commander In Chief'? Evaluating President Bush's Claims Against a Key Supreme Court Executive Power Precedent |work=FindLaw |date=January 5, 2006 |quote=That signed statement shows, in microcosm, how the President sees the separation of powers: The President, in his view of the world, can interpret away constraints on his power, such as those in the McCain Amendment, or FISA before it. And the courts can hardly question his dubious 'interpretations' even if they gut the very statutes they construe: After all, there are 'constitutional limitations on the judicial power'—though not, apparently, on the power of the executive.}} Critics acknowledge that part of the President's duty is to "interpret what is, and is not constitutional, at least when overseeing the actions of executive agencies," but critics accused Bush of overstepping that duty by his perceived willingness to overrule U.S. courts.{{cite news |last=Van Bergen |first=Jennifer |url=http://writ.news.findlaw.com/commentary/20060109_bergen.html |title=The Unitary Executive: Is The Doctrine Behind the Bush Presidency Consistent with a Democratic State? |work=Findlaw |date=January 9, 2006 |quote=In his view, and the view of his Administration, that doctrine gives him license to overrule and bypass Congress or the courts, based on his own interpretations of the Constitution....}} ==See also== *[[Presidential system]] *[[Parliamentary system]] *[[Independent agencies of the United States government]] *[[Federal Reserve Board]] *[[Executive branch]] *[[Signing statement]] *[[Imperial Presidency]] *''[[The Imperial Presidency]]'' (book) *[[War on terror]] *[[State of exception]] ==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}} ==Bibliography== {{refbegin}} * {{cite book |editor-last1= Barilleaux |editor-first1= Ryan J. |editor-first2= Christopher S. |editor-last2=Kelley |lastauthoramp= yes |title= The Unitary Executive and the Modern Presidency |publisher= Texas A&M University Press |year=2010 }} Essays by presidential scholars on the origins, history, use, and future of the unitary executive theory, with particular attention to the presidency of George W. Bush. * {{cite book |last1= Calabresi |first1= Steven |last2= Yoo |first2= Christopher |lastauthoramp= yes |url= https://books.google.com/?id=4sJhrLROSc8C&printsec=frontcover&dq=Yoo+and+%22unitary+executive%22 |title= The Unitary Executive; Presidential Power from Washington to Bush |publisher= Yale University Press |year= 2008|isbn= 0300145381 }} * {{cite book |last1= Kurland |first1= Philip |last2= Lerner |first2= Ralph |lastauthoramp= yes |url= http://press-pubs.uchicago.edu/founders/tocs/a2_1_1.html |title= The Founders Constitution, Article 2, Section 1, Clause 1 }} *{{cite journal |last= Percival |first= Robert V. |title= Presidential Management of the Administrative State: The Not-So-Unitary Executive |journal= Duke Law Journal |year= 2001 |volume= 51 |issue= 3 |page= 963 |url= http://www.law.duke.edu/shell/cite.pl?51+Duke+L.+J.+963 |doi= 10.2307/1373182 |jstor= 1373182 }} *{{cite web |last= Rudalevige |first= Andrew |url= http://www.press.umich.edu/titleDetailDesc.do?id=17468 |title= The New Imperial Presidency}} *{{cite journal |last1=Yoo |first1= Christopher |last2= Calabresi |first2= Steven |lastauthoramp= yes |title= The Unitary Executive during the Second Half-Century |journal= Harvard Journal of Law & Public Policy |year= 2003 |volume= 26 |issue= |pages= |url=http://www.allbusiness.com/legal/3585817-1.html }} *{{cite journal |last= Yoo |first= Christopher |first2= Steven |last2= Calabresi |first3= Laurence |last3= Nee |lastauthoramp= yes |title= The Unitary Executive During the Third Half-Century, 1889–1945 |ssrn= 559581 |journal= Notre Dame Law Review |year= 2004 |volume= 80 |issue= | pages= }} *{{cite journal |last= Yoo |first= Christopher |first2= Steven |last2= Calabresi |first3= Anthony |last3= Colangelo |lastauthoramp= yes |title= The Unitary Executive in the Modern Era, 1945–2004 |ssrn= 690822 |journal= Iowa Law Review |year= 2005 |volume= 90 |issue= 2 |pages= 601 }} {{refend}} {{US Constitution}} [[Category:Presidency of the United States]] [[Category:United States law]] [[Category:Counter-terrorism in the United States]] [[Category:United States national security policy]] [[Category:George W. {{Infobox IPA | above = Uvularized | ipa symbol = ◌ʶ }} {{Place of articulation}} '''Uvularization''' is a [[secondary articulation]] of [[consonant]]s or [[vowel]]s by which the back of the tongue is constricted toward the [[uvula]] and upper [[pharynx]] during the articulation of a sound with its primary articulation elsewhere.
==IPA symbols== In the [[International Phonetic Alphabet]], uvularization can be indicated by the symbol {{IPA|⟨ʶ⟩}} (a superscript [[voiced uvular approximant]] (inverted small capital R)) after the letter standing for the consonant that is uvularized, as in {{IPA|[tʶ]}} (the uvularized equivalent of {{IPA|[t]}}).
==Occurrence== Uvularized consonants are often not distinguished from [[pharyngealized consonant]]s, and they may be transcribed as if they were pharyngealized.
In [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and several other [[Semitic languages|Semitic]] and [[Berber languages]], uvularization is the defining characteristic of the series of "[[Emphatic consonant|emphatic]]" [[coronal consonant]]s.<ref>McCarthy, John (1994) "The phonetics and phonology of Semitic pharyngeals. In Keating (ed.) ''Phonological structure and phonetic form: papers in laboratory phonology III'', 191–233. Cambridge University Press.</ref><ref>Shahin, Kimary (1996) "Accessing pharyngeal place in Palestinian Arabic", in Eid & Parkinson (eds.) ''Perspectives on Arabic Linguistics: Papers from the Ninth Annual Symposium on Arabic Linguistics, Washington DC, 1995'', 131–149</ref>
Uvularized consonants in standard Arabic are {{IPA|/sʶ/}}, {{IPA|/dʶ/}}, {{IPA|/tʶ/}}, {{IPA|/ðʶ/}}, {{IPA|/lʶ/}}. Regionally there is also {{IPA|/zʶ/}} and {{IPA|/rʶ/}}. Other consonants, and vowels, may be phonetically uvularized.
In [[Greenlandic language|Greenlandic]], long vowels are uvularized before [[uvular consonant]]s.<ref>Sydney Wood (1997) "The gestural organization of vowels and consonants: a cinefluorographic study of articulator gestures in Greenlandic", 5th European Conference on Speech Communication and Technology</ref>
